facts.text: Appellant filed nomination paper for election to the Madras Legislative Assembly from the Namakkal Constituency in Salem district.
On the 28th November, 1951, the Returning Officer scrutinized nomination papers and rejected the appellant's nomination paper on certain grounds.

Appellant moved the Madras High Court under article 226 of the Constitution praying for a writ of certiorari to quash the order of the Returning Officer rejecting his nomination paper and to direct the Returning Officer to include his name in the list of valid nominations.

Madras High Court dismissed the appellant's application on the ground that it had no jurisdiction to interfere with the order of the Returning Officer by reason of the provisions of article 329 of the Constitution.
Appeal filed to the Supreme Court against the High Court's order.

legal_issues.text: Whether the High Court has jurisdiction under Article 226 to issue a writ of certiorari to quash the Returning Officer's rejection of a nomination paper before the election, or whether such matter can only be called in question by an election petition under Article 329(b).
Meaning of the word 'election' in Article 329(b) - whether it refers only to the final result or the entire process culminating in the declaration of a candidate as elected.

petitioner_arguments.text: The conclusion arrived by the High Court does not follow from the language of Article 329(b), whether read by itself or along with other articles in Part XV.
Anomalies, hardships, or prejudice will arise if the High Court's construction is accepted, such as inadequacy of post-election remedy.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sarvothama Rao v. Chairman Municipal Council, Saidapet (1924) I.L.R. 47 Mad. 585

petitioner_arguments.text: Word 'election' in Article 329(b) means the result of polling or final selection of a candidate, not pre-polling stages like nomination scrutiny.

Scrutiny of nomination papers under Section 36 of Representation of the People Act, 1951 is subject to High Court's jurisdiction under Article 226 as the Act is under Article 327 which is subject to Constitution.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 36, Representation of the People Act, 1951; Article 327

petitioner_arguments.text: Contrast with Article 71(1) suggests Article 329(b) does not cover all disputes including nominations.
If nomination is part of election, Returning Officer has no jurisdiction under Section 36 as Article 329(b) vests it in tribunal.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 36, Representation of the People Act, 1951; Article 329(b)

respondent_arguments.text: High Court has no jurisdiction under Article 226 due to Article 329(b); election matters only via election petition.
Post-election remedy via election petition is adequate; pre-election interference causes public inconvenience and delays democratic process.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Desi Chettiar v. Chinnasami Chettiar (1928) A.I.R. Mad. 1271

court_reasoning.text: Word 'election' in Part XV, including Article 329(b), has wide meaning denoting entire process culminating in candidate being declared elected, not narrow sense of final result.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Election embraces whole procedure to return a member; supported by precedents like Srinivasalu v. Kuppuswami.

court_reasoning.text: Article 329(b) prescribes manner and stage for questioning election: only by election petition after election; bars High Court jurisdiction under Article 226 at intermediate stages.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme of Part XV and Representation of the People Act, 1951 provides single remedy via election petition.

court_reasoning.text: Hardship to individual secondary to public interest in completing elections without obstruction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Elections must proceed per time schedule; disputes postponed till after.

court_reasoning.text: Where statute creates right/liability and special remedy, that remedy alone; applies to election law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Wolverhampton New Water Works Co. v. Hawkesford principle.

court_reasoning.text: Section 36 scrutiny is stage in election process, not questioning election itself; Returning Officer acts administratively.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Improper rejection ground under Section 100, but only via petition.

court_reasoning.text: Historical consistency with English law and pre-Constitution rules supports exclusion of court jurisdiction pre-election.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Language of Article 329(b) mirrors prior provisions.

holdings.text: High Courts have no jurisdiction under Article 226 to entertain petitions challenging rejection of nomination papers; such matters only via election petition under Article 329(b).
'Election' in Article 329(b) means entire process from nomination to declaration.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sarvothama Rao v. Chairman Municipal Council, Saidapet

precedents_cited.relevance: Adequacy of election petition; public inconvenience of delays.
Wide meaning of 'election' as whole procedure.
Agreement with wide meaning of election.

precedents_cited.case_name: Wolverhampton New Water Works Co. v. Hawkesford
Neville v. London Express Newspaper Limited
Attorney-General of Trinidad and Tobago v. Gordons Grant Co.
Secretary of State v. Mask Co.
Hurdutrai v. Official Assignee of Calcutta

precedents_cited.relevance: Election jurisdiction special and final; no interference.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Part XV scheme bars High Court interference; election only questioned by petition.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Scrutiny by Returning Officer; grounds for voiding election including improper rejection; exclusive remedy by election petition; no civil court jurisdiction.

outcome.summary: The appeal against the Madras High Court's dismissal of the writ petition is dismissed, affirming that High Courts have no jurisdiction under Article 226 to interfere with Returning Officer's rejection of nomination paper; matter only via election petition under Article 329(b).

key_quotes.text: "Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution... no election shall be called in question except by an election petition..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Text of Article 329(b) central to holding.

key_quotes.text: The word election has been used in Part XV of the Constitution in the wide sense, that is to say, to connote the entire procedure to be gone through to return a candidate to the legislature.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: It seems to me that under the election law, the only significance which the rejection of a nomination paper has consists in the fact that it can be used as a ground to call the election in question.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Having regard to the important functions which the legislatures have to perform in democratic countries, it has always been recognized to be a matter of first importance that elections should be concluded as early as possible according to time schedule...
key_quotes.speaker: court
